text: - On this episode,

we showcase the journey
of HERE Technologies,
a world leading location platform

that's transforming how
their customers interact

with digital representations
of the physical world.
Hear about their collaboration
with the AWS Prototyping team,

where they've developed a
next-generation search platform

that seamlessly converts
natural language query

into advanced automotive
driving simulations and scenes.

Well, I'm excited to
welcome Kristin Thompson,

Senior Product Manager
for Advanced Driving
for HERE Technologies.
Kristin, thanks so much for joining us.
- Thank you for having me.

- And also joining us
from HERE Technologies,
we have Julian Gonsior,

Senior Product Manager
for Automated Solutions.
- Thanks, pleasure.
- From AWS, we have Shane Madigan,
our Senior Engagement Manager
for WorldWide Prototyping.
Shane, thank you for being here.
- My pleasure, great to be here.
- And also we have Patrick O'Connor,

our Prototyping Engineer
from our WorldWide team.
Patrick, great to see you again.
- Great to see you again, thanks.

- Well, Kristin, for
our WorldWide audience,

can you tell us a little
bit about HERE Technologies
and your mission?
- Yeah, absolutely, so HERE Technologies

is we're the world's leading
location platform company.
We have a strong global footprint
and presence in the automotive space.

We primarily do a lot of
business-to-business work
with in-car navigation systems,
ADAS systems, and automotive driving.

- So for listeners who
might not be familiar
with the automotive space,
can you explain what ADAS means?

- Yeah, so ADAS is advanced
driver-assistance systems.

So the systems inside
the vehicle that enable
advanced driving technology with the car

performing some of the
driver functionality.
- Wonderful, and I understand Julian,
you both work in this space.
Can you tell us a little bit
about what you were trying to achieve?
- So one of our missions

is that we are making the
lives of our customers easier.

So the main customers
are the automotive OEMs

and we are helping them to
develop the right products
in the automated driving domain.
So we are helping, for example,
level 2+, level 3 systems.
So level of autonomy to bring them

and help them bring their
systems to the market.
And we do that with highly automated

and high definition
products that we do have,

like HERE's HD Live Maps
or our high definition map.
- And those levels define the level
of complexity and automation?
- Exactly, it's SAE levels,

the Society of Automotive
Engineers who define these levels.
There is like a scale from 1 to 5
and where we come into the game

is everywhere from 0 to 4
at the moment, I would say,
there is not really 5 at the moment,
but the levels really interesting are L2+.
It's not a real official level,
but L2+ is everything
where you can basically take your hands
off the steering wheel.
You still have to watch the street,
but you can take your hands off for

and find time on the road,
for example, in Germany,
and you drive from Munich to Berlin
and can take off your hands there.
And level 3 is basically where the car
really takes over the driver's task
and you can also read a book, for example,
and have your eyes off the road.
- Hmm-mm, okay.
Exciting times, right?
Tell us a little bit
about what we were trying to achieve here.

- So we do have, as I
already touched a little bit,

our high definition map
here is HERE's HD Live Map.

And we are using that already
together with our customers
for in-car introduction use cases.

And together with AWS,
we wanted to find out,
can we also help our automotive customers

to use our product that we
do have on shelf already
for development use cases?
So help them within their development task

and help them within
simulation activities.

So use it to general virtual
environments, for example.

- And that simulation
helps reduce the cost,
as I understand it,
for all the testing that has to happen.
Is that right?

- Absolutely, so if we can
help automotive customers

to generate synthetic
scenes out of our map,
out of our HD Live Map,
we can drive costs down for them

and we can also help them
being faster to market
in their autonomy projects and programs.

- Absolutely, and all
different scenarios, right?
The complexity of the scenarios
that you're able to simulate.

- Absolutely, I mean,
there is a difference
between scene and scenario.

So based on our map, we
are creating the scene.
So that is basically the part of the world
that goes into the virtual environment.
Scenario is then if you add

like dynamic information
as vulnerable road users,
for example, traffic and so on.
- Fascinating, so Kristin,

can you tell us a little bit
about how you came to work
with AWS and the team?
- Absolutely, so HERE and AWS

have had a pretty
longstanding relationship.

We leverage AWS's products
within our own ecosystem

and it is something
that we've wanted to do
is really expand our partnership
with Amazon and AWS in general
because we see a lot of opportunities
for us to work together.

And this was something
that we were interested
in partnering with AWS on
because we had the opportunity
to really leverage our assets

and also the assets that
Amazon brings to the table
and AWS with development.
So we bring the data,
the map data for this situation.
And from that data, of course,
all of these different scenes
that Julian was mentioning can be created.
It's real-world data.
So it it's highly valuable
from an automotive testing perspective.
And AWS would bring to the equation,
you know, the scalability of the system,

the ability to run the simulation
in a cloud environment.
And also their natural language processing
and AI capabilities
for enabling a good user experience
for identifying scenarios and scenes
and doing search of our data.

So it seemed like a natural
pairing for us to work with,
with AWS on this opportunity.
- Great, and Shane,
can you talk us through a little bit
about what the scope of the project was?

What were we trying to
achieve with this prototype?

- So we were introduced to
HERE through the account team.
And so we worked with HERE,

to make sure we understood
their business challenge first,

we wanna make sure as our
first engagement with 'em,

we really understood what
they were trying to achieve
in the environment that they work in.
And so we quickly kind of worked down
through what their needs were
and to a few key successful criteria
and a few key objectives.
And so the focus of this prototype
was really on a few things.
First and foremost was to create
a streamlined data extract process
out of their tiling system.
It's incredibly complex, as I mentioned.

I think if I've heard
the website correctly,
they got a thousand different parameters,
sorry, in that tiling system.
So that was the first thing,
is how do we get the data out of that

and then merge it into a
format that is breathable.
The second half of that project,

the second major objective
was then to apply
generative AI capabilities
to create that natural language interface

to allow the end user to
quickly use natural language

to find and identify those
scenes that they're looking for
for their simulation testing.
- Kristin, what are in these tiles,
this complex data?

- Yeah, so the tiling
system is really a way
of breaking down the world

into small loadable and
manageable chunks, right?
So a tile is a a four-by-four rectangle.

And you're probably
familiar with seeing that

in, you know, consumer
mapping technologies.

You can see, you know,
this is how you can zoom in
and zoom out, right?
Based on the tile configuration.
But the tile has a section of road,
depending on how detailed you wanna get.

You can get, you know,
really zoom in and see
on the, you know, per-kilometer basis
what is, you know, the representation
of the world, right?
And so within the tile data structure,

you need to be able to
have all of the features

that are present in
reality within that tile.
- Got it, got it.
So over to you, Patrick.

Can you talk us through a
little bit of the architecture
that you used in the prototype?
- Yeah, sure, so from the discussion,

you can kind of hear that
there was two main segments.
I break it down into the ingestion pattern
and then the query pattern.

So the way we went about
this in the prototype

is we intentionally
boxed these two functions
into Step Functions, a service on AWS
that allows us to orchestrate
these complex systems.
So with the ingestion pattern,
what we decided to do

was we needed something
that was capable of scaling,

but also leveraging some of
the serverless capabilities.
So in that ingestion Step Function,
we utilized the service AWS Blu.

You would've heard
illustrations about these tiles.

Each of these tiles
contain a complex joint
of different nodes and linkages.

So with Blu, what we were
able to do is we were able
to essentially stitch these tiles together

and pump them out into another
service known as OpenSearch,
a queryable system.
Now on the query side of things,
so this query Step Function,
we then leveraged a logical path
to be able to decipher
the user's query;

for example, find me a
road on an intersection.
We use natural language queries

to then convert this
into a queryable system
that we can then run against OpenSearch,
leveraging Amazon Bedrock
and LLM managed service on AWS.

- Nice, and you talked
about the scalability.

Maybe Kristin, can you give
us an idea of that scale.
In the end state,

what kind of complexity are
we looking at and scope?

- So the complexity, so
from a scale perspective,
for example, on the tiling scale,

you know, we have hundreds
of thousands of tiles
at continental scale, right?

So there's a lot of complexity
within the tile structure.
And then the data structure, right?
Is very complex within it.

So because we have to have
the data representative

of the entire road
infrastructure globally.

So when you're talking about,
you know, the amount of data,
it's very complex and very heavy.

- Got it, and then moving
then to the NLP area
where you're going to allow your users
then to construct queries
and interrogate the data

and the systems to set
up these simulations,
is that the next step?

- Yes, so a bit more on
the natural language.

So whilst we're using
Bedrock and Step Functions,

more specifically, we're
leveraging capabilities
such as tool use.
So that's quite a new feature on Bedrock
that allows us to extract specifically
the aspects we're looking for.

But the next steps of
this queryable section
is that we take in the natural language.

We then prompt it using
prompt engineering.
We ask it specifically to generate
a queryable system similar to SQL,

but specific to OpenSearch
leveraging tool use,
so if you're joining points there,
to generate that query.
We then query OpenSearch,
seeing if we get the appropriate results.
If we don't, we rehearse this.
So we reverberate as what I like to say,
correcting the prompting each turn,
I believe configurable up to 10 times.
But each time you query,
you can actually finally tune it

so that you guide the LLM
to the query you're seeking.
- So Shane, we've built,
sounds like we've made some progress
building some components to the prototype.
What were the key milestones
that we were trying to achieve here?
- Yeah, great question.
So as I mentioned earlier,

every time we begin an
engagement with a customer,

we go through a working
backwards approach.
And I mentioned earlier
the business challenge and the objectives,
but one of the other big things we do

is try to come to what those
core success criteria are
for the customer in this prototype.
We wanna make sure that we are,
we have kind of a true north

that we know we're hitting
the big ticket items
that are gonna help move them forward.
And in this case,

the three things that
we really focused on,

one was creating kind
of a scalable pipeline
to ingest the data from their tile system.

As you've heard, it's
very, very extensive.
The second part is really putting that
into a queryable database
for use by the end user.

And then, the third piece
really being important

is that natural language
component that allows a user
to search, find, and obtain

really those scenes that
they need in that instance.

- So Kristin, maybe you
can zoom out for us.
Can you help contextualize

why these three aspects were
so important to test out
and what they mean in the overall context
of the work that you're doing?
- Yeah, absolutely, so I think

that this is really a critical
thing for our customers

because they do so much of
their testing and simulation.

You know, it's been
discussed that, you know,

for the industry, you know,
for a fully automated vehicle

to come to market, it might
take somewhere in the realm
of 8 billion miles of driving
to test all different kinds of scenarios.

We know some companies
that do a thousand X
the miles in simulation versus in reality
because right now, there are only two ways

to actually test these
systems is, you know,
in reality or in simulation.

And so for some companies
that means getting out there
and driving every mile,
we know customers who have driven

every kilometer of every
lane of the network

before actually bringing
the functionality to market.

And so having the ability
to also, you know,

do large-scale simulation
testing is a really powerful tool

to expedite bringing some
of these products to market.
So having the ability to take, you know,

a scalable pipeline where
you could do, you know,

multiple simulations
running at the same time.
And also a large data set of our data

where you can, you know, from
the customer perspective,

they can surface different
situations in reality

that they would like to
encounter and test in simulation.

And then also that natural
language processing

for, again, really the human
interaction with the data
and making this, you know, something

where a customer could say,
okay, I'd like to test,

you know, a highway
where there's four lanes,
and you know, a motorway interchange,
and you know, look for various features
in our data and surface that up
and find that information really quickly
so that way they can then throw it
into the simulation and test it.
- And Patrick you were able to build in

that ability to do those
kind of more complex queries?
- Yeah, exactly.
So as Kristin was referencing before,
we've created an interface to be able

to just naturally write a
question you're looking for.

So one of the tests
that we ran from memory

was find me a road that
is accessible by cars

but not accessible by buses
or trucks, for example.

You can actually test that
from that second Step Function.
So you can go through the individual steps
and see it query the database.
So we use DLQ, dashboard language query,
which is the SQL version
of querying Amazon OpenSearch.
And then you can see it go through
and say, Hey, it found a road,

but a bus can go on it
so that's not right.
So we pass it back into the query system

and then we go again and
again till eventually,
we find the correct query that addresses

whether it's an easy
query or complex query.

The language model is able to
break down the core components

and generate the result
you're looking after
or you're looking for rather.
- And if I may add to that,

because that is so
important for our customers
is you can search for real-world data

on publicly available
large language model,
but the output is not the same

'cause the output here
is automotive grade,
it's hallucination free.

So you really get what
you search for exactly.

And that was the target
for our prototype here.
- Oh, that's wonderful to hear.
So we often talk in this podcast
because it's about innovation,

that it's not an experiment
if you know the answer, right?

And that innovation and
failure are inseparable twins.
There's something here
that was particularly challenging

or something that didn't
work the way we expected

and we had to maybe take
a different direction,
Patrick, maybe from a technical standpoint
or even process wise?

- Yeah, yeah, so there
was a few modifications

that we made definitely chart
the prototype of discovery.

One thing I think is a
highlight to prototyping,
but also a challenge is acting as a portal

to be able to interface
with the client's data.
So we kind of heard the concept of tiles,

this is very specific to
HERE and their storage.
And as part of the prototype
and the ingestion pipeline,
we went through this phase of discovery

in understanding the link
between layers, let's call them.
So layers within a tile,
they all have this joining factor
that could vary from a road to a junction,
but they all have this linking together,
which internally to HERE is knowledge.
But part of the prototype was us mapping

that knowledge they had
into a system or service
that they could then easily configure.

So originally, we had
been looking at ideas
such as using PySpark on EMR.
We were potentially just looking
at Lambdas be able to join us,

but we found that AWS
Blu was the better portal
to be able to do this A,

for the reason that you could
just run a Python environment.

So you have other
configurable environments,
but Python seemed logical;

and B, Blu has a much
more enhanced feature.
And being able to scale across ETL jobs.

That was one of the challenges
that took a little of time

of talking to people
like Kristin and Julian
and discovering what that link was.

But once we were able
to establish a baseline,
we were then able to jump over to Blu,
create that join but also push that
into the OpenSearch queryable database.

So Julian, maybe we can go over to you.

So I understand that it is

to actually take the

Can you tell us a little

- So thank you for that.

So I can tell you it's
been a hell of a ride
to develop this any further.
And I can tell you, so from the prototype,

we are currently going
from prototype stage,

I would say, to POC stage,
so to a proof of concept.

And this proof of concept
we are developing further.

So what we have talked
about is like the first part
of our proof of concept now,
so finding the right scene.
What is so important for our customers

is getting the scene
into the right format.

So we added another portion
to our proof of concept.

So we can generate scenes
now in the OpenDRIVE format.

And OpenDRIVE is the
industry standard format
for simulation.

So customers can basically
now search for a scene,
get multiple results,
pick the right scene,

and directly convert them
within our tool into OpenDRIVE

and perfectly ingest them
in any SIM platform software
that is out there in the market.

And that is the part of
the proof of concept.

I'm already starting

So we are doing that in terms

of getting the right
customer feedback to it,

like getting early traction
to the proof of concept,

but also getting requirements
like understanding,

is that really meeting the
needs of our customers?

If not, we are going
back and changing things.

And from there, I have
a lot to do actually
because it drives me to productization.

So how to create a real product
out of the proof of concept.
And that means we need to talk
about the business model, for example.

So how is that going to
be sold to our customers?
What are the TNCs behind that
to create a real product out of it then?
- Wonderful, well thank you all
for being here with us today.

I'm just wanting to
end on some reflections
and I'll start with you Patrick.
What did you learn from this prototype

you have experienced
across multiple industries?
What did you learn on this one?
- So working with HERE,

I think was a real end-to-end
experience in the sense

that you have the visual
cue being the simulation.

The gen AI aspect of mapping
something dynamic to structured
and then a huge scalable ingest.

It's my first time working
with kind of geo-positioned
or geographical data points.

So one thing I did learn
is just the vast size
of mapping data in general.

It stunned me that we restricted
the prototype to a geo,
but just understanding the intricacies,

I can definitely see
why a platform like AWS
hits a few critical aspects
such as ingest query and output.

So yeah, that was one thing
that really I reflect back on

is just the vastness of
mapping data in general.

And once you're able to
streamline this process,

there's a lot more use cases
that open up at the end.
- Something we all use on a daily basis,
but take for granted about.
Shane, how about you?

Any reflections that you would
share with our listeners?
- Yeah, my biggest reflection
from this engagement is really,

and it's something we talk
about in every engagement,

but it's the concept of
the engaged stakeholder.
As Patrick's hinted at,
we're not mapping experts.
We bring experts in AWS technology
and in rapid prototyping,
but we are not the experts in mapping.

And that was the most
important thing in this project
that led to the success

is how engaged HERE was from
the very beginning to help

essentially teach us
much about their business
that we had not been exposed to before.

So I think, you know, not
only in this engagement,
but all of them was a critical factor

and is really one of
the most important items

when we look at what makes
a prototype successful.
- So important and exciting too

to bring that people from
different areas of expertise
together towards a common goal.
Julian, how about you?
What would you reflect on?

- I have to say, it was
for me also the first time

working together with AWS
and the best about it,
it doesn't end.

So I still engage more
and more together with AWS
and I can just say I enjoy it so much
because the people within AWS,
it's just what makes me smile every day

because there is such
an intrinsic motivation

in all the AWS folks I'm
working together with
to make our products even better.
And it's a partnership approach

that we bring something
together to the market
that is even better as a joint team.
- Well, that's wonderful to hear.
Thank you for that.
And Kristin, final words for you,

what reflection or guidance
would you give to listeners

who might be undertaking
a similar journey?
- Yeah, I think, you know,
one of the things that, you know,

Julian and Shane touched
on as well, right?

This was really about
the value of partnerships
and we have our expertise in mapping
and automated driving.

Amazon has their expertise in
the scalability of the systems
and some of the AI components.
And when you really lean on your partners
and solicit engagements with folks
who have expertise in other areas,

then you can actually
bring something, you know,
really remarkable and unique to the market

that you might not be
able to do on your own.

- Lovely, well, Kristin,
Julian, Shane, Patrick,
thank you for being here today.

- Thanks for having me.
- Thank you.
